author: sky.cactus
content: ~~This is not correct.~~ This is correct.

author: sky.cactus
content: Per the spec, as <@543900561460822016> pointed out, base fee starts at 0 and works its way up as full blocks come in.

author: sky.cactus
content: We can expect a number of full blocks immediately after the fork while the base fee catches up and equalizes things.

author: sky.cactus
content: I don't believe we ever said that the base fee would start at some large number, even in older versions of the spec.  I may be wrong on this but I did try hard to not leave anything out when converting to code.

author: sky.cactus
content: You are right though, we should clarify that `expected_base_fee = parent_base_fee - fee_delta` is bounded by `0`.

author: sky.cactus
content: Anyone happen to know of an easy and clear way to express that in Python?

author: sky.cactus
content: <@574864862338088960> To be clear, I'm not outright against setting some starting base fee that is greater than 0.  I'm only arguing here that the spec doesn't say that and I don't *think* it ever said that.

author: sky.cactus
content: Ah, just checked and you are right <@574864862338088960>!  The initial base fee was in fact 1 nanoeth.

author: sky.cactus
content: I'll submit a PR to address both of these issues (the lower bound clamp at 0 and initial base fee of 1000000000).

author: sky.cactus
content: Is there any reason to include the effective gas price in the transaction receipt?

content: It feels like maybe there is?
